title: A number theory problem by Anubhav Jain
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A number when divided by a divisor leaves a remainder of 24. When twice the original number is divided by the same divisor, the remainder is 11. What is the value of the divisor?"}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"let the number be 'x' and the divisor be 'd' ."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"By division algorithm , "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x = dm + 24 .......... (1)"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2x = dn + 11 ........... (2)"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Multiplying (1) by 2 , "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2x = 2dm + 48 ........ (3)"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Equating (2) , (3) ,"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"dn + 11 = 2dm + 48"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"dn - 2dm = 48 - 11"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"d( n - 2m) = 37"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Since  37 is a prime number and d,n,m are positive integers , only 2 cases come into consideration -"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1) d = 1 ; n - 2m = 37"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"But if d = 1 , then d | x ."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So remainder must be 0 always! "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So , d = 1 is not possible."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2) So we are left with the only case , d = 37 , which is possible."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Hence , the required divisor is 37 :)"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Let the original number be 'a'"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Let the divisor be 'd'"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Let the quotient of the division of a by d be 'x'"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Therefore, we can write the relation as a by d = x and the remainder is 24."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"i.e., a = dx + 24"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"When twice the original number is divided by d, 2a is divided by d."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"We know that a = dx + 24. Therefore, 2a = 2dx + 48"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The problem states that 2dx + 48 by d leaves a remainder of 11."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2dx is perfectly divisible by d and will therefore, not leave a remainder."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The remainder of 11 was obtained by dividing 48 by d."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"When 48 is divided by 37, the remainder that one will obtain is 11."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Hence, the divisor is 37."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Nice calculations."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"However, I would like to point out that when finding the minimum possible value of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \overline{abc} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", you want to minimize "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" then "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"b"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" then "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"c"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", as opposed to the other way around. E.g. To find the smallest 3-digit number that is a multiple of 3, you'd want "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" a = 1, b = 0, c = 2 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". As opposed to saying "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" c = 0, b = 0, a = 3 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"This doesn't affect your solution, because there is a unique value of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"c"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"b"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Hence, instead of saying"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"blockquote","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
  "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"c=7"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" will be the "},{"type":"text","text":"least number possible","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" to give us unit digit as 1."}]},{"type":"text","text":"
"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"it should instead be"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"blockquote","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
  "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"c = 7 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is the "},{"type":"text","text":"only possible value","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" to give us unit digit as 1."}]},{"type":"text","text":"
"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Likewise for the case of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"b"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", and the case of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is properly written.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Basically, we are looking at the numbers that can be multiplied to 123 to produce the digits 001. For example, for the units digit, only 7 can be multiplied to 3 to obtain a number with a units digit of 1.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Indeed, you should have mentioned in your solution that you used the technique of Euclidean Algorithm to find the multiplicative inverse. That will help others understand how you worked it out (instead of plucking the number magically from thin air).

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            gcd(1000, 123) = 1, so we can apply the extended Euclidean algorithm: 
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1000 - 123 * 8 =16"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"123 - 16 * 7 = 11"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"16 - 11*1 = 5"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"11 -5*2 = 1"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"Plugging back in backwards, we find that:"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"11-(16-11*1)*2 = 1\rightarrow 3*11-2*16 = 1"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3*(123-16*7)-2*16 = 1\rightarrow 3*123-23*16=1"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3*123-23*(1000-123*8)=1\rightarrow 187 * 123-23*1000=1"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"So "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"187*123\equiv1(mod1000)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":".

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Assume "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"N=\frac{}{abc}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", where a is the hundred's digit, b is the ten's digit, and c is the one's digit."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"We know that the ones digit has to be 1. The ones digit of the final product is the is the ones digit of the product of the ones digits of 123 and N. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3N=\frac{}{f1}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", where f is a single digit number. The only number that works is 7, because "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3*7=21"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The ten's digit is the sum of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"((2*7+2)+3c"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" So "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"16+3c"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" has to have a one's digit of zero. The only number that adds with 6 to get some number of zero is 4. So "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3c=\frac{}{d4}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", where d is another single digit number. 3*8=24, so the ten's digit is 8. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"At this point it would be easiest to simply do guess and check, since we narrowed it down to 10 numbers."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"123*87=10701"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"123*187=23001"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"187 gives us a product of 23001, so the answer is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\boxed{87}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

                                            answer = 187"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"00861
09840"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"heading","attrs":[{"level":1}],"content":[{"type":"text","text":"12300"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"23001"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"to get 1st digit "1" in 001 , 3 in 123 should be multiplied by 7"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"so 7 is units digit of N"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"units digit of 123 * 7 = 861 
6 need 4 to be 0 in 001
so the next number is 8 as 8*3 = 24"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"just swim in space :(

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Sorry , forgot to mention that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" must end in "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" in the "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2nd"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" line.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"See ..we go by the intuitive approach..
first step is to multiply with 7(as to get 1 in the last pos)
then see which next number gives you a sum 0...
continue till u get the last 3.. :)"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"We know that 3*(last digit of N) has last digit of 1. The only number from 0-9 that satisfies this condition is 7. Therefore we know that the unit digit of N = 1."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Let the number be xy7
123*7 = 861"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"codeBlock","content":[{"type":"text","text":"        123
       *xy7
"}],"attrs":[{"text":"        123
       *xy7
","language":null}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"horizontalRule"},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"codeBlock","content":[{"type":"text","text":"        8 6 1
 y(2y)(3y)
   (3x)
"}],"attrs":[{"text":"        8 6 1
 y(2y)(3y)
   (3x)
","language":null}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"By the good old multiplication by hand method, last digit of (3"},{"type":"text","text":"y+6) = 0 *(or (3","marks":[{"type":"italic"}]},{"type":"text","text":"y+6)%10 = 0)*
This implies that (3*y)%10 = 4, smallest y = 8. 6+24 = 30, bring over 3 to left side."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(3+8+2"},{"type":"text","text":"y+3","marks":[{"type":"italic"}]},{"type":"text","text":"x)%10 = 0
(3+8+16+3"},{"type":"text","text":"x)%10 = 0
(27+3","marks":[{"type":"italic"}]},{"type":"text","text":"x)%10 = 0
(3*x)%10 = 3
x = 1."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Thus, smallest "},{"type":"text","text":"N = 187","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

title: 0^0 is indeterminate!
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\\large \\displaystyle \\lim_{x \\rightarrow 0} \\left ( \\sum_{n = 0}^{\\infty} x^n \\right )"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"\n\n"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Find the value of the expression above."}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\displaystyle \left ( \sum_{n = 0}^{\infty} x^n \right )"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"=1+x+x^2+x^3+x^4........."}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Let "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"y=1+x+x^2+x^3+x^4........"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\rightarrow y-1=x+x^2+x^3........ \\ \rightarrow y-1=x(1+x+x^2+x^3....) \\ \rightarrow y-1=xy \\ \rightarrow y-xy=1 \\ \rightarrow y(1-x)=1 \\ \rightarrow  y=\frac{1}{1-x} \\ \rightarrow\large \displaystyle \lim_{x \rightarrow 0} \left ( \sum_{n = 0}^{\infty} x^n \right ) = \displaystyle \lim_{x \rightarrow 0} (\frac{1}{1-x}) = \frac {1}{1-0} = \boxed{1}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Upvote it if you liked it !"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

Hence, we have,"}]},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\lim_{x\to 0^+} 0^x=\lim_{x\to 0^+} 0=0\\ \lim_{x\to 0^-} 0^x=\lim_{x\to 0^+}\frac 1{0^x}=\textrm{(undefined)}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Since the left-hand limit at "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x=0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" doesn't exist (is undefined), the given two-sided limit doesn't exist."}]},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"horizontalRule"},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"I have no good problems to give you since they'll all be easy for you. :| "}]},{"type":"text","text":" "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            "},{"type":"text","text":"[Response to Challenge Master Note]","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"By "solve this using Big O Notation", did you mean the following?"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\begin{aligned}\lim_{x\to 0}\sum_{n=0}^\infty x^n&=\lim_{x\to 0}\bigg(x^0+\mathcal{O}(x)\bigg)\\&=\lim_{x\to 0}\bigg(1+\mathcal{O}(x)\bigg)\\&=\left(\lim_{x\to 0}1\right)+\left(\lim_{x\to 0}\mathcal{O}(x)\right)=1+0=1\end{aligned}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Here, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\mathcal{O}(\cdot)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is the Big O Notation.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

                                    "}]}

                                            Good solution

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The mistake was first made in Step 4, where we went from a sum with "},{"type":"text","text":"even","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" number of terms, in which the sum is indeed 0, to a sum with "},{"type":"text","text":"arbitrary","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" number of terms (which has no limit of partial sums).   "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Subsequently, in step 5, we went from a sum with an arbitrary number of terms, to a sum with "},{"type":"text","text":"odd","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" number of terms, in which the sum is indeed 1."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"horizontalRule"},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Step 1 is justified since "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 0 = ( 1- 1 ) "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
Step 2 is justified since we're just adding 0. "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
Step 3 is justified as taking the limit, namely "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \sum_{i=1}^{\infty} (1-1) = \lim \sum_{i=1}^n (1-1 ) = \lim 0 = 0 "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
Step 4 is wrong as explained above. "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
Step 5 is wrong as explained above. "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
Step 6 is justified."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            I think you are confused between speed and average speed. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Speed or instantaneous speed is the magnitude of the velocity. Whereas, average speed is total distance traveled by total time taken.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            But that's velocity 
Speed= Distance/Time and Velocity = DISPLACEMENT/Time
Speed is a scalar, "Velocity" is a VECTOR quantity!

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            You talk about velocity without talking about the referential system according to which you are calculating this velocity!. Let's put the referential (o,x,y,z)  on the car  wheel axis, the whole car will be at rest relatively to this system  except the wheel that is spining around it. In this case, the point will not be at rest because you have just one vector which is tangential to the wheel and cannot be canceled. Isn't it ?.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"It is very surprising at first that how can a moving rigid object have a point on it that is at rest. However, it's possible in a way that the point does not remain at rest forever rather it's instantaneous speed that is zero. In the next instant, the bottom most point is changed and some other point of the wheel takes this position."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Unless the tire is skidding/slipping, the contact points must have equal velocities. Hence, the bottom most point remains at rest."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Moreover, if the bottom most point has a velocity in the direction of motion of the car. The car is said to be skidding forward. This case generally occurs when hard brakes are applied on a moving vehicle. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Similarly, if the bottom most point has a velocity opposite to the direction of motion of the car. The car is said to be going under backward skidding. This situation generally occurs when tires are stuck in the mud and we try to accelerate the car. In this case, the tire rotates more than moving forward."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

replies.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Yes, I agree with you. The concept of the instantaneous axis of rotation is helpful in many cases. Like in this case, we can write the kinetic energy of the wheel directly as "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac{1}{2} I_{bottom} \omega^2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":".

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

comments.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Nice explanation! It seems counter intuitive that point is at rest because it's at rest only for an instant. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"We can often use the fact that the point is instantaneous rest to simplify calculations. We can assume the wheel to performing purely rotational motion and no translation about this point. This is known as the instantaneous axis of rotation.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

Hence, if the velocity is zero so does the speed. "}]},{"type":"text","text":" "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"mention","content":[{"type":"text","text":" @Martin Ramsch – "}],"attrs":[{"profile":""}]},{"type":"text","text":" I agree, caterpillar tracks is a great way to visualize this! "}]},{"type":"text","text":" "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"mention","content":[{"type":"text","text":" @Pranshu Gaba – "}],"attrs":[{"profile":""}]},{"type":"text","text":" If you replace the wheel with caterpillar tracks, it is becoming absolutly obvious: Each plate of the tracks is placed on the ground once per turn, lying motionlessly on the ground for a short time, until it is lifted off again (and transported forward on the upper side with double speed in relation to the ground)."}]},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Motion is always relative, and only makes sense in regard to a reference system. The wheel turns continuesly und all its surface points move—relative to the axis(!)—with constant angular speed, resulting in this case to 100 mph constant linear speed (seen relative to the axis!). But in this problem the ground is meant to be the reference system. "}]},{"type":"text","text":" "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"mention","content":[{"type":"text","text":" @Paul Palmer – "}],"attrs":[{"profile":""}]},{"type":"text","text":" In the frame of the car, the bottom most point of the tyre moves backwards with velocity "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\omega r"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". The car itself is moving forward with velocity "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\omega r"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Adding vectorially, the velocity at bottom most point in the ground frame is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\omega r - \omega r = 0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". "}]},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Any point on the wheel moves in the shape of a cycloid. Note that its speed approaches zero when it touches the ground. "},{"type":"image","attrs":{"src":"https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/6/69/Cycloid_f.gif"}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":" "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            @Pranshu Gaba Sorry, no connection between the two examples. The acceleration remains constant in both cases. The speed of every point on the circumference of the wheel is constant though the velocity keeps changing as its direction changes. In the ball example, the acceleration is the constant acceleration of gravity. Yes, the speed passes through the value zero at the top but zero is just some number it goes through, just like it goes through other numbers. You can't put your mind on an instant of zero duration and then pretend that it is the same as an instant of finite duration because our minds can't easily encompass zero duration any more than they can infinite duration. The only thing we can do is to view a single point as a limit. Before it touches the ground (at every point actually) a point on the wheel is moving at a finite speed. After the contact, the same point is moving at a finite speed. Condense that down to the limit as it touches the ground and the limit is  still the same speed.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            If we throw a ball vertically upwards, what would be its speed when it is at its topmost point? It would be zero, even if it is just for an instant. It would have a non-zero speed before and after it is at the topmost point. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"We can use a similar argument for the bottommost point of the wheel.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

comments.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            The explanation which says the that point on the wheel in contact with the ground is at rest is off the mark. The wheel is a rigid object. All the points on its circumference are moving at the same rotational speed and linear speed which depends on its radius and circumference. The car is moving at 100 mph so any point in contact with the ground, absent skidding, must be moving backwards with respect to the car at 100 mph. True its position, x, is a particular point at time t. But the first derivative of x with respect to time, dx/dt is -100 mph with respect to the car and wrt to the ground at that moment. The moment passes instantaneously as that point on the tire lifts off the ground. This is reminiscent of Zeno's paradox about the flight of an arrow which purposely confuses the position of an arrow with its speed. At each moment, the arrow is at a particular location but it is not at rest at that location. Just because the ground is at rest does not mean the wheel is at rest. That would be true if they were in contact for any finite time, but they are not. Instantaneity is not finite.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

title: 0.101010... in base 3?
body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"In base ten,  "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(0.\overline{10}) =\frac{10}{99}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"What about in base three?"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"What is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(0.\overline{10})_3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"? "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Give your answer to 3 decimal places in base 10."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Notation:","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":"  "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"bulletList","content":[{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"0.\overline{10} = 0.10101010101010\ldots "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". "}]},{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The subscripts indicate the base."}]}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Here are two ways to approach this one:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1) "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(0.101010...)_3 = \frac{1}{3^1} + \frac{1}{3^3} + \frac{1}{3^5} + ...  = \frac{3}{8} = \boxed{0.375}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2) Let "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x = (0.101010...)_3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"bulletList","content":[{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"100_3 x = (10.101010...)_3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"100_3 x - x_3 = 10_3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"22_3 x = 10_3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x = \frac{10_3}{22_3} = \frac{3_{10}}{8_{10}} = \boxed{0.375}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}
